metadata./Keywords: Ectopic pregnancy; Ipsilateral; Salpingectomy; Recurrent; Tubal pregnancy; Case report
metadata./Title: Ipsilateral ectopic pregnancy in the distal remaining part of the previously removed Fallopian tube: a case report
metadata./Producer: Acrobat Distiller 10.1.8 (Windows); modified using iText® 5.3.5 ©2000-2012 1T3XT BVBA (SPRINGER SBM; licensed version)

sections.Background:
Background Ectopic pregnancy, occurring outside the uterine cavity, poses a significant health risk, with Fallopian 
tube involvement being predominant. Recurrent ectopic pregnancy, particularly in the ipsilateral remnant of a pre viously removed tube, is a rare and poorly understood phenomenon. Here, we present a case of recurrent ectopic 
pregnancy occurring in the distal remnant of the right fallopian tube following ipsilateral incomplete salpingectomy 
in a 22-year-old woman.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation A 22-year-old woman of mixed Arab ancestry and African ethnicity, gravida 4, para 1, with a history of one miscarriage and a previous ectopic pregnancy, presented to Elshatby Maternity Hospital, Alexandria, 
Egypt, complaining of severe lower abdominal pain with a history of an open right salpingectomy one year prior due 
to the ectopic pregnancy. She exhibited stable vital signs on admission. Ultrasound revealed a 6-week gestational sac 
in the right fallopian tube, accompanied by hematoma and mild pelvic collection. Despite analgesic interventions, her 
symptoms worsened the next day, prompting open surgery. Surprisingly, the distal portion of the right tube, which 
was supposed to have been removed in the prior salpingectomy, contained the ectopic pregnancy. A laparotomy 
was performed, involving evacuation of the pelvic hematoma, distal ipsilateral tubal salpingectomy, and peritoneal 
lavage. Postoperative recovery was uneventful, with improvement demonstrated during follow-up.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion Caution should be taken when dealing with any woman in the reproductive age group who presents 
with acute abdomen, especially if she has a previous history of ectopic pregnancy, to exclude the possibility of recur rent ectopic pregnancy. Previous salpingectomy does not exclude the possibility of recurrent ectopic pregnancy 
on the ipsilateral side, as the inappropriate surgical technique used during salpingectomy can affect the possibility 
of recurrence. We suggest that careful clinical consideration of the surgical technique used during salpingectomy 
is essential to minimize the risk of recurrent ectopic pregnancies and prevent serious complications.
Keywords  Ectopic pregnancy, Ipsilateral, Salpingectomy, Recurrent, Tubal pregnancy, Case report
sections.Introduction:
Introduction
Ectopic pregnancy, also known as extra-uterine preg nancy, derives its name from the Greek term “ektopos, ” 
which signifies being out of place [1]. Ectopic preg nancy  is believed to be found in as many as 1–2% of 
pregnancies in the USA. However, this may be an under estimate, as this condition is often managed in office set tings where it is not routinely tracked [2].Open Access

*Correspondence:
Mohamed Mohamed Belal
Mohamed.abdo1801@alexmed.edu.eg
1 ElShatby Maternity University Hospital, Faculty of Medicine, Alexandria 
University, Alexandria, Egypt
2 Faculty of Medicine, Alexandria University, Alexandria, Egypt
Page 2 of 4 Elshatby et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:644 
Ectopic pregnancy is a significant issue during the 
first trimester of pregnancy due to its high morbid ity and mortality [3, 4]. In the majority of ectopic preg nancy  cases, the fallopian tube emerges as the primary 
location [5, 6].
Women who have experienced an ectopic pregnancy in 
the past are at a higher risk of developing another ectopic 
pregnancy, and this risk increases in proportion to the 
number of previous ectopic pregnancies. In a study con ducted by Shaw et al., the odds ratio (OR) for having an 
ectopic pregnancy was 12.5% after one previous ectopic 
pregnancy and 76.6% after two [7]. Additionally, women 
who have undergone prior tubal surgery, such as salpin gostomy, neosalpingostomy, fimbrioplasty, tubal reanas tomosis, or lysis of peritubal or periovarian adhesions, 
also face an increased risk of developing ectopic preg nancy [8]. The extent of this risk is dependent on the 
degree of damage and the extent of anatomical alteration 
[8].
Ectopic pregnancy ruptures are the main reason for 
maternal deaths in the first trimester of pregnancy, 
accounting for 9–14% of cases and occurring in 5–10% of 
all pregnancy-related deaths [4]. The precise cause of an 
ectopic pregnancy occurring on the same side as a previ ous tubal surgery is not fully understood. Various theo ries have been proposed to explain this phenomenon. 
One theory suggests that the egg may still be fertilized 
in the fallopian tube stump by sperm traveling through 
the open tube, into the cul-de-sac, and then through the 
damaged tube. Another possibility is that the fertilized 
egg migrates from the opposite ovary through the open 
tube, passes through the uterus, and implants in the 
remaining fallopian tube stump. Additionally, it is possi ble that the remaining tubal stump retains some degree 
of openness after surgical ligation, even though it is typi cally closed off during a salpingectomy procedure [9].
In this report, we present a case of recurrent ectopic 
pregnancy in the distal remnant part of the right fallo pian tube after an ipsilateral partial salpingectomy.
Case presentation
A 22-year-old female patient of mixed Arab ancestry and 
African ethnicity, gravida 4, para 1, experienced one mis carriage and one ectopic pregnancy in her right fallopian 
tube. She also has a history of a previous caesarean sec tion and has been married for 3 years. According to her 
last menstrual period, which was on 4 September 2023, 
she was approximately 6 weeks pregnant.
She came to the ER of Elshatby Maternity Hospital, 
Alexandria, Egypt, on 17 October 2023 complaining of 
severe lower abdominal pain that started several hours 
earlier and gradually intensified, accompanied by fatigue 
and shortness of breath, particularly when in a supine position, with no significant previous medical history. 
Surgically, the patient had a previous uncomplicated 
cesarean section 2 years ago, and previous dilatation and 
evacuation for 2 months missed abortion. Additionally, 
she underwent an open right salpingectomy via a Pfan nenstiel incision 1 year ago due to a previous ectopic 
pregnancy at a private hospital. She did not use an intra uterine contraceptive device (IUCD) previously, and she 
was on combined oral contraceptive pills for 9 months. 
By history, she did not experience any previous episodes 
of foul-smelling vaginal discharge accompanied by fever, 
and she had not been diagnosed with pelvic inflamma tory disease (PID). She had only experienced two previ ous episodes of candida infection.
Her vital signs were stable. The serum level of betahuman chorionic gonadotropin (β-hCG) on admission 
was 9280 IU/L. Guarding made abdominal examination 
difficult. However, tenderness all over the abdomen was 
significant, particularly in the left lower abdomen. Local 
examination revealed a soft closed cervix, accompanied 
by minimal vaginal bleeding.
Ultrasound demonstrated an empty, anteverted, and 
flexed (AVF) uterus with a pseudo-decidual reaction. 
The left adnexa were free. However, in the right adnexa, 
there was a gestational sac in the right fallopian with a 
non-pulsating fetal pole with Crown rump length (CRL) 
measuring approximately 6 weeks surrounded by a 
hematoma measuring about 4 × 5 cm with a mild pelvic 
collection and free morisons and lieno-renal pouch. The 
patient did not have risk factors for her recurrent ectopic 
pregnancy except for previous history of ectopic preg nancy 1 year ago.
The patient was monitored in the emergency depart ment, but the symptoms’ severity escalated despite 
analgesic interventions. Additionally, there was a deterio ration in vital signs, with a pulse of 120 beats per minute, 
blood pressure of 100/50 mmHg, and an augmentation of 
pelvic collection.
Due to the severe symptoms and the unavailability of 
a laparoscope at that time, the patient underwent lapa rotomy via Pfannenstiel incision. Surprisingly, the distal 
portion of the right tube, which was supposed to have 
been removed in the previous salpingectomy, was occu pied by the ectopic pregnancy. No proximal part of the 
previously removed tube was  present (see Fig.  1). The 
contralateral tube ovary and tube were intact (See Fig. 2).
Evacuation of the pelvic hematoma, distal ipsilateral 
tubal salpingectomy, and peritoneal lavage with warm 
saline was carried out. Subsequently, closure was under taken following the assurance of adequate hemostasis.
The patient’s postoperative recovery was uneventful. 
She was discharged and went home on the first postoper ative day. During the outpatient follow-up 2 weeks later, 
Page 3 of 4
 Elshatby et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:644 
 
she demonstrated improvement, as indicated by a decline 
in β-hCG levels to less than 5 IU/L.
Case
sections.Discussion:
discussion
Ectopic pregnancy is any pregnancy outside the uter ine cavity. It represents about 2% of all pregnancies. The 
most common site of ectopic pregnancy is the ampulla 
of the Fallopian tube, which represents about 92% of all 
ectopic pregnancies. Recurrent ectopic pregnancy ranges 
in general from 6% to 28%, but recurrent ectopic preg nancy in the ipsilateral Fallopian tube is a rare condition 
with an unknown percentage [3, 4, 10].
The risk factors for ectopic pregnancy are any previous 
tubal surgery, intrauterine devices, genital tract infec tions, any previous pelvic/abdominal surgery, smoking, 
and vaginal douching [3, 10–12].
Similar to our case, Zuzarte et  al. in 2005 and Chou 
et  al. in 2006 reported two different cases of recurrent 
ipsilateral distal tubal ectopic pregnancy. Additionally, 
Chun-Sen Hsu in 2008 presented two cases of spontane ous recurrent tubal ectopic pregnancy; one of them was 
located within the distal part of the tube following ipsilat eral salpingectomy for a previous ectopic pregnancy [13, 
14]. Similarly, Samiei-Sarir et  al. in 2013 reported two 
cases of spontaneous recurrent tubal ectopic pregnancy. 
However, both were located within the proximal remnant 
tube following ipsilateral salpingectomy for a previous 
tubal ectopic pregnancy [15].
The mechanism by which ectopic pregnancy recurs in 
the remnant part of the previously removed Fallopian 
tube (ipsilateral recurrent ectopic) is not clearly under stood. Still, different theories can explain this rare phe nomenon. Sperm migration through the patent tube, into 
the Douglas pouch, then transperitoneal migration to the 
contralateral ovary to fertilize the ovum on the damaged 
tube, can explain this phenomenon [13, 16–20].
Another explanation is the fertilization of the ovum in 
the healthy tube, then transuterine migration to the con tralateral damaged tube and implantation in it [13, 17–19, 
21]. The reconnection between the distal and proximal 
part after salpingectomy and then recanalization (in case 
of long stump remaining) may occur with implantation in 
the isthmic part of the damaged tube [13].
Conclusion
Due to the significantly elevated mortality rate associated 
with recurrent ectopic pregnancy, being about 10–15fold higher than any other type of ectopic pregnancy, 
caution should be taken during salpingectomy. It is essen tial to avoid leaving an extended proximal stump of the 
tube, ensure adequate cauterization after tubal ligation to 
prevent recanalization of both tube ends, and of course 
verify the complete removal of the already damaged 
Fig. 1 Intraoperative findings: proximal part of the right Fallopian 
tube, which was previously removed in a previous ectopic pregnancy 
(orange arrow), the posterior wall of the uterus (yellow arrow), 
the right intact ovary (black arrow), the fimbria of the right Fallopian 
tube (green arrow), intact tubal gestational sac in the distal part 
of the right Fallopian tube (blue arrow)
Fig. 2 Intraoperative findings: intact fimbrial end of the contralateral 
Fallopian tube (green arrow), intact ovary (black arrow), intact 
proximal portion of the Fallopian tube (blue arrow)
Page 4 of 4 Elshatby et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:644 
tube. Additionally, attention should be given not to leave 
the fimbria or distal part of the tube by mistake during 
salpingectomy.
